sen.e: Waichiro MOTOI (1843 - date of death unknown) was from 粕崎 Kariwa-gun Echigo Province and belonged to Shinsengumi for only a short time.

sen.j: 名主元井森右衛門の子として生まれたが、兄・鯛蔵と仲が悪く、安政5年（1858年）5月に家出して、上野伊勢崎の伯父・栄吉のもとに住み着く。
sen.e: He was born as a son of myoshu (owner of rice fields), Moriemon MOTOI, however he didn't get along with his older brother, Taizo, and he left home in June 1858 to settle in the house of his uncle, Eikichi, in Ueno Isesaki.

sen.j: 文久元年（1861年）、今度は縁戚・乕吉のもとに移り、文久3年（1863年）には江戸神谷町の商家越後屋万吉のもとを訪ねた。
sen.e: In 1861, he moved to his relative, 乕吉's house, and in 1863 he visited Mankichi ECHIGOYA's, a mercantile house in Kamiya-cho Edo.
In 1861, he moved to his relative, Torakichi's house, and in 1863 he visited Mankichi ECHIGOYA's, a mercantile house in Kamiya-cho Edo.

sen.j: 元治元年（1864年）10月、新選組局長近藤勇による隊士募集に応じて一時新選組へ入隊するが、京都へ向かう前に脱退。
sen.e: Although he applied for recruitment of Shinsengumi members by the leader, Isami KONDO, and joined Shinsengumi in October, 1864, he left Shinsengumi before going to Kyoto.

sen.j: 越後屋の紹介で神奈川奉行所管轄の見廻方に就任し、和一郎と名乗る。
sen.e: Through the introduction of Echigoya, he took office as Mimawariyaku (the role of patrol) of Kanagawa Magistrate's office and he assumed the name Waichiro.
He took office as Mimawariyaku (the role of patrol) of Kanagawa Magistrate's office through Echigoya, and he assumed the name Waichiro.

sen.j: 戊辰戦争が勃発すると、徳川幕府が崩壊して給料が得られなくなってしまったため、帰郷を決意。
sen.e: When the Boshin War broke out, he decided to return his home, because the Tokugawa shogunate broke down and couldn't get salary.

sen.j: 途中、佐野藩で古屋佐久左衛門率いる一隊（後、衝鉾隊）に遭遇し、なかば強制的に所属させられる。
sen.e: On his way home, he met with a troop led by 古屋佐久左衛門 (Sakuzaemon FURUYA ?) (later, Shoho-tai) in the Sano Domain, and was almost forced to join it.

sen.j: 会津に着くと、正式に兵糧方を任され、各地に従軍。
sen.e: When they got to Aizu, Waichiro was formally appointed as the role of army provisions, and followed the army in various places.

sen.j: 仙台で榎本武揚艦隊と合流して蝦夷地へ渡った。

sen.j: 箱館戦争降伏後、静岡藩預かりとなり、明治3年（1870年）3月、赦免。
sen.e: After their surrender in Hakodate War, he became in custody of the Shizuoka clan, and was pardoned in April, 1870.
